timeline: Early December (Day 23-24 of story, approximately 3 weeks after Ch1)
location: Turning Torso - building management office (floor 2), stairwell, Saga's apartment (floor 28)

knows: Filed eight complaint tickets in three weeks
All eight tickets closed with 'no system errors detected'
Apartment temperature now at 18.5°C (worse than Ch1)
Elevator issues, access card failures, WiFi problems continue
Erik's dashboards show all systems operating 'within parameters'
Erik attributes her problems to stress, confirmation bias, or 'perception issues'
Biometric enrollment would provide 'full integration' and allegedly reduce issues by 81%
Erik's job performance is measured by operational efficiency and complaint metrics
She's being classified as a 'problem resident'
Erik essentially told her to comply or leave
Viktor has also been keeping records of problems
Pattern emerging: non-enrolled residents have issues, enrolled residents don't
Saga.emotional_state: Angry, validated in her suspicions but gaslit by 'data,' realizing the trap, determined to prove pattern
Saga.resistance_level: Moving from individual complaint to systematic investigation - connecting with Viktor

knows: Saga has filed eight tickets in three weeks
All diagnostics show 'no errors'
Saga continues to refuse biometric enrollment
Her complaints are impacting his performance metrics
She's not going to comply easily
His job is to maintain high enrollment rates and low complaint tickets
Erik.emotional_state: Frustrated with 'difficult resident,' believes he's being reasonable, genuinely thinks data proves him right
Erik.tactics: Institutional gaslighting through data authority, suggesting medical/psychological causes, framing biometric refusal as choosing 'degraded service'

knows: Has been experiencing similar issues to Saga
Has been keeping his own records
Saga wants to compare notes

revealed_to_reader: Saga has filed eight tickets in three weeks, all closed as 'no issue found'
Apartment temperature has dropped from 19°C to 18.5°C (escalation)
Erik called the meeting to address Saga's 'repeated complaints' (she didn't request it)
Erik's dashboards show all systems as 'green' and 'within parameters'
Erik attributes Saga's problems to stress, confirmation bias, or physiological issues
Erik explicitly states complaint tickets impact building performance metrics
Biometric enrollment allegedly reduces resident issues by 81%
Only 3% of residents are non-enrolled (97% enrollment rate)
Non-enrolled residents average 4.7 tickets per month vs 0.3 for enrolled
Erik essentially gave Saga an ultimatum: enroll, leave, or stop complaining
Erik closed all eight tickets immediately after the meeting
Saga is forming 'Biometric Divide Hypothesis' - pattern recognition beginning
Saga and Viktor are meeting tomorrow to compare notes

planted.element: Erik's performance bonus structure and metrics obsession
planted.significance: Explains why Erik dismisses complaints and pushes biometric enrollment - his job performance depends on it
planted.subtlety: PAYOFF - Erik explicitly states that complaint tickets impact building performance metrics

planted.significance: Only 3% of residents are non-enrolled - small group to target with 'optimization pressure'
planted.subtlety: Mentioned as proof of system success, actually reveals how isolated resisters are

planted.element: Saga's architect training and documentation skills
planted.significance: Her methodical logging of issues leads to hypothesis formation
planted.subtlety: She's compiled 12 pages of building issues log, now forming 'Biometric Divide Hypothesis'

planted.significance: Saga and Viktor will compare notes and confirm pattern
planted.subtlety: Coffee meeting scheduled for tomorrow to compare data

planted.element: Correlation between enrollment and complaint rates
planted.significance: Erik's own data reveals the pattern: non-enrolled residents have 15x more complaints
planted.subtlety: Erik presents this as proof biometrics help; Saga recognizes it as evidence of systemic discrimination

active_tensions: Saga vs Erik (institutional authority dismissing individual experience)
Subjective experience vs 'objective' data (gaslighting through metrics)
Privacy rights vs system optimization (false choice between data surrender and degraded service)
Erik's belief in his righteousness vs actual complicity in coercion
Saga's growing certainty of pattern vs lack of proof
Individual resistance vs systemic pressure (comply or leave)
world_changes: Apartment temperature has dropped from 19°C to 18.5°C (escalation of pressure)
Erik has formalized his position: no more investigation without diagnostic confirmation
Saga is now officially classified as 'problem resident' in building metrics
Saga moving from individual complaint to systematic investigation phase

incidents_logged.details: Erik called formal meeting to address Saga's 'repeated complaints'
Eight complaint tickets filed: climate, elevator, access card failures, WiFi problems, package delivery, lights flickering
All eight tickets closed simultaneously as 'RESOLVED - NO ISSUE FOUND'

foreshadowing_elements: Saga forming 'Biometric Divide Hypothesis' - will be confirmed in Ch6
Erik's suggestion Saga should 'consider if this building is right for you' - foreshadows eventual choice to leave or submit
Saga scheduling meeting with Viktor to compare notes - leads directly to Ch6 pattern discovery
Erik's statement about 'efficient use of resources' - reveals optimization logic driving system
Saga's observation about 'optimization creating incentives for compliance' - she's figuring it out
Erik's genuine belief in the data - shows how easy it is to enable oppression through metrics
Temperature continuing to drop - pressure escalates when resistance is detected
scene_structure: Opening: Erik's meeting request email, corporate-friendly but ominous tone
Scene 1: Saga prepares for meeting, checks temperature (18.5°C now)
Scene 2: Erik's office - he presents dashboard showing all systems 'green'
Scene 3: Erik suggests stress, confirmation bias, even medical issues as explanation
Scene 4: Erik pitches biometric enrollment as solution, shows enrollment/complaint correlation data
Scene 5: Saga refuses, Erik's friendliness disappears
Scene 6: Erik's ultimatum - explicit statement about metrics and limits of support
Scene 7: Saga leaves, climbs stairs to floor 28
Scene 8: Back in cold apartment, Saga formulates 'Biometric Divide Hypothesis'
Closing: Saga texts Viktor to meet, realizes she needs to prove the pattern
emotional_arc: Apprehension (called to meeting) → frustration (dismissed again) → anger (gaslit with 'data') → clarity (recognizing the trap) → determination (must prove pattern exists)
gaslighting_techniques_demonstrated: Authority of data - Erik's dashboards as 'objective truth' vs Saga's 'subjective perception'
Medical explanation - suggesting stress, confirmation bias, circulation issues, iron deficiency
False choice framing - presented as 'limited service' not discrimination
Reasonable tone - Erik believes he's being helpful and rational
Responsibility reversal - 'you're choosing degraded service' not 'system is punishing non-compliance'
Efficiency justification - can't investigate 'perceived problems without diagnostic confirmation'
Suggesting departure - 'maybe this building isn't right for you'
Immediate ticket closure - demonstrating power to dismiss all complaints
erik_character_dynamics: Corporate speak masking coercion - 'setting reasonable expectations,' 'efficient use of resources'
Metrics obsession - references building performance metrics, satisfaction scores, enrollment rates
Performance incentives revealed - complaint tickets impact his operational efficiency ratings
Genuine belief in righteousness - truly thinks data proves he's correct
Complicity through optimization logic - doesn't see coercion, sees 'natural consequences of data limitation'
Emotional shift when challenged - friendliness cools to professional coldness when Saga won't comply
Power through dismissal - closes all eight tickets in single action after meeting
escalation_to_chapter_6: Saga has formulated 'Biometric Divide Hypothesis' in writing
Meeting scheduled with Viktor to compare documented patterns
Saga recognizes need to prove systemic discrimination, not just individual problems
Temperature continues to drop - pressure increasing
All institutional complaint channels have been closed off
Saga moving from 'problem resident' phase to 'investigation' phase
next_chapter_setup: Saga meets Viktor at café. They compare their incident logs and discover the pattern: all problems correlate with non-biometric enrollment. Chapter 6 'The Pattern' (tentpole) - the major revelation that shifts story from personal problem to systemic discrimination.
